feed.title: Interview: Death Cab For Cutie Still Dealing with Ottawa Stage Collapse
feed.subtitle: It was the most memorable concert they never played... Death Cab For Cutie are still dealing with the ramifications of a stage collapse July 17 at Ottawa Bluesfest.

link.title: Death Cab For Cutie

link.Abstract: Get the latest music news, interviews and album reviews
link.title: Get the latest music news, interviews and album reviews
Follow Dose.ca on Twitter

content.div:
How might Death Cab For Cutie’s Nick Harmer describe the band’s trip to this July’s Ottawa Bluesfest? Memorable, maybe?

“Ooooh, yeah. Definitely,” says the bass player over the phone, some two weeks after what he terms a “now famous -- or infamous -- non-performance.”

Non-performance? For those not already following Harmer’s Twitter account (@onewhoharms) -- or the latest headlines on Canadian festival disasters -- here’s a quick rundown:

July 17, Death Cab For Cutie were preparing to play the Bluesfest mainstage when a storm struck. “This black cloud of just menace was coming toward the entire festival,” recalls Harmer, who watched the weather turn sinister from the side of the stage. According to the Ottawa Citizen, winds of 96 kilometres per hour whipped through the festival grounds that day. And around 7:20 p.m. -- shortly after performers Cheap Trick (and others including Ottawa’s mayor) had been evacuated from the stage -- everything caved in, leaving a twisted mess of debris, and some eight people injured.

“I have never seen wind blow an entire stage flat. I'm in shock. All dcfc band and crew narrowly escaped disaster,” Harmer Tweeted at the time, in between sharing pictures of the flattened stage and other in-the-heat-of-the-moment impressions. (Another sample Tweet that comes to mind: “Seriously. What. The. F*ck.”)

“We’re still sorting out the ramifications of all that,” says Harmer of the Ottawa disaster weeks after the fact.

He means more by that than the reflective indie-rockers’ struggle to schedule a possible make-up date (though Harmer offers that, “Yes, there are plans about coming back to Ottawa and doing something.”)

“The bigger issue -- the most immediate issue for us -- is trying to cover a lot of band gear that was buried under the stage,” he reveals.

Instruments, amps, all manner of assorted equipment -- some of it custom-made or vintage and “impossible to replace” -- was destroyed when the stage went down, Harmer says.

(Though Cheap Trick were the band on stage at the time of the disaster, Harmer explains that the bulk of Death Cab’s gear was stowed behind the classic-rockers’ set-up, ready to go for the next festival slot on the stage.)

“When the stage collapsed, most of our gear was buried,” Harmer says -- explaining he personally lost “everything but my bass guitars.

“And even today, they’re still working on un-burying the stage, or sort of pulling it apart. We have received some of our stuff back -- a lot of it broken, a lot of waterlogged stuff, we’re still piecing together our rig.”

Harmer says all this the day after Death Cab launched its current leg of North American touring in Columbus, OH. “A lot of things broke in the middle of the set that we thought were fine,” he says with a resigned chuckle. “So it’s going to be a while until we’re back to 100 per cent of where we were at right before that show.”

That said, reviews have been favourable. (The Montreal Gazette’s write-up on last weekend’s Osheaga Festival set made note of some audio glitches -- though they also mentioned technical set-backs couldn’t keep Death Cab from tugging at a few thousand heartstrings with their performance.)

Besides, equipment -- even the “lucky gear” and custom pieces Harmer now misses -- can eventually be replaced.

“For us, nobody got killed, and you know all the rest of it is just material stuff we can put back together,” he says. (The band’s insurance, he notes, will help as they buy everything back.) “We had some technical problems last night, like I said, but we’ve got a lot of good shows ahead of us.”

The band continues to play through the States all August, and earlier this week they announced a new set of North American shows, scheduled to begin September 30 in Cincinnati. (A Vancouver show, October 21 at Rogers Arena, is the sole Canadian addition.).

Harmer mentions how the present trek feels like the “first proper tour” for the group’s seventh and current album, Codes and Keys.

This spring, around the time that record arrived, much was made of how life had changed for the four guys in Death Cab: Harmer, frontman Ben Gibbard, guitarist/producer Chris Walla and drummer Jason McGerr. Gibbard had famously married actress/musician Zooey Deschanel; Harmer himself married last year. McGerr became a father.

Many reviewers noted Codes and Keys’ new warm and cozy palette (a dulcet mix of electronic and analog elements) and its warm and cozy lyrics (“Monday Morning” is reportedly a doting portrait of wife Deschanel, for instance; lead single “You Are a Tourist” swells with hope on its opening verse: “When there's a burning in your heart…/Build it bigger than the sun/Let it grow, let it grow”). Perhaps Death Cab is getting a little less emo -- and a lot more contented -- now that they’re family men in their 30s.

But having families to come home to had more practical effects on the making of album. The record was recorded in bursts -- spans of no longer than two weeks -- so that the musicians wouldn’t spend too much time away from their loved ones.

Making time for their new families has been a priority while arranging the touring side of their careers, as well. There was never any hesitancy about booking months’ worth of travel, Harmer says. “The simplest answer is, if anything, we just have far more conversations about making it manageable,” he says.

“When Plans came out there was one year where we were on the road for 200 days out of the year, and that’s just not healthy,” he laughs, talking about the group’s 2005 major-label debut. “That’s hard -- hard on your body, hard on your mind.

“We were definitely going to tour,” Harmer continues, explaining how there wasn’t a question the band would take off for long stretches to bring Codes and Keys to the fans.

“But we also definitely want to be back in the studio as well,” he reveals of their future plans.

“We had a great time recording Codes and Keys and I think if we had a choice, just because it was so exciting recording Codes and Keys, we’d be back in the studio sooner than later,” he says -- though he adds that “nothing definite” has been planned.

He would, however, say this: “I think there will be less time between Codes and Keys and our next album than there was between Narrow Stairs (2008) and Codes and Keys (2011). I can feel that already.”

Death Cab For Cutie Play Vancouver October 21.
